item.title: Does Europe Have a Financial Nuclear Option?
item.author: Patrick Boyle
item.content:encoded:

The recent Greenland crisis at Davos 2026 has shattered transatlantic trust, forcing Europe to confront a terrifying new reality: the need for strategic autonomy from the United States. Faced with what it views as transactional coercion, Brussels is readying an arsenal of economic countermeasures, ranging from a "trade bazooka" targeting U.S. tech firms to the highly publicized "financial nuclear option"â€”the threat of dumping trillions in U.S. Treasuries. But before we panic about a bond market collapse, we need to examine the hard financial realities: Is weaponizing sovereign debt a viable strategy, or is it merely a macroeconomic suicide pact? This video dives into the mechanics of this potential economic war and the high cost of moving from an era of global efficiency to one of fearful autarky

item.title: The Neretva in Bosnia - A wild river on the brink of collapse | DW Documentary
item.author: DW Documentary
item.content:encoded:
The Neretva in Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of Europe's last wild rivers. Its unique ecosystem is threatened with destruction. Despite objections, politicians and entrepreneurs are allowing hydroelectric power plants to be built here. But resistance to the plans remains strong.
Over the past millennia, the Neretva has developed into a globally unique ecosystem. It is home to animal and plant species that exist nowhere else. But the "Blue Heart of Europe,â€ as the Neretva is also known, is threatened with collapse.
Politicians and entrepreneurs see new power plants as opportunities to generate sustainable energy â€” and rake in big money. Local residents and scientists, on the other hand, have serious doubts about the projects. This is because the construction of a dam changes the natural environment forever.
Boban Å krtar lives a few kilometers above the planned main dam in the village of Ulog. On the riverbank, he explains the devastating impact of the construction project to date: "Everything here used to be forest. It was cleared for the dam, and you can see that now everything is destroyed. There used to be a swimming area and a campsite there, but now everything is gone forever." On the other side of the dam, Austrian aquatic ecologist Kurt Pinter is searching for the softmouth troutâ€”a fish thought to live in just four river systems, including the Neretva. His hope is that if the softmouth trout is declared an endangered endemic species in this part of the river system, the construction of some 70 new power plants along the Neretva may be prevented.

item.title: Prince Albert - The Obsession of Queen Victoria Documentary
item.author: The People Profiles
item.content:encoded:
Explore the dramatic true story of Prince Albert, the man who became Queen Victoriaâ€™s obsession and reshaped the British monarchy. This in-depth biography documentary follows Albertâ€™s journey from a little-known German prince to the powerful Prince Consort at the heart of Victorian Britain.
Discover how Prince Albertâ€™s intense partnership with Queen Victoria transformed royal power, public morality and the very image of the royal family. We trace his role in politics, foreign policy, empire, industry, the Great Exhibition of 1851 and the creation of the modern constitutional monarchy.
This history documentary dives into the emotional core of Victoria and Albertâ€™s marriage â€“ devotion, control, jealousy, grief â€“ and shows how that private obsession had huge consequences for Britain and the wider world. See how Albert fought scandal, hostile ministers and anti-German prejudice while building a new royal role based on duty, respectability and progress. Ideal for viewers interested in the Victorian era, British royal history, European monarchy, 19th century politics and character-driven history documentaries.

item.title: The Listener - Witnesses to the Holocaust | DW Documentary
item.author: DW Documentary
item.content:encoded:
Dori Laub pioneered a radical form of listening. The psychiatrist and Holocaust survivor began recording the stories of other survivors in the late 1970s. This is a film about the power of listening.
When Dori Laub began recording the stories of other survivors in the late 1970s, he was preserving memory. But he was also pioneering a radical act of listening. He recognized the power of listening to life stories as a way of helping survivors cope with trauma. His work led to the creation of the worldâ€™s first video testimony archive and shaped a unique therapeutic approach centered on presence, empathy, and witness.
The documentary follows the final four years of Laubâ€™s life (2015-2018), interweaving powerful archival testimonies with intimate glimpses into his own story: a childhood in Romanian camps, a love affair with the daughter of a former Nazi officer, and the moment his own children hear his testimony for the first time. His legacy echoes today in the work of Edut 710, a project inspired by Laubâ€™s methods to document the voices of survivors of the October 7 Hamas massacre.

item.title: Why is Trump obsessed with Minneapolis? | Today, Explained
item.author: Vox
item.content:encoded:
Minnesota has become ground zero for the biggest federal immigration operation in US history. Thousands of immigration officers are patrolling the streets of Minneapolis, leading to the death of one anti-ICE protester, Renee Nicole Good, and setting off a massive swirl of protests.
Vice President JD Vance visited Minneapolis late this week â€” showing his support for law enforcement, and sending a political message at the same time: that this White House is doubling down on its war against blue cities, and Minneapolis specifically.
Now, President Trump has subpoenaed the stateâ€™s top Democratic officials, alleging they were impeding federal immigration enforcement actions. The Justice Department has promised to arrest anyone who impedes the immigration enforcement actions, and a Trump official accused some state officials of â€œterrorism.â€ With Minnesota now in a full-blown conflict with the Trump administration, the Democratic state leadership is front and center in the standoff.
In this video episode of Voxâ€™s Today, Explained podcast, host Astead Herndon interviews Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison about the Somali fraud scandal that first brought on the ICE surge in his state. Did Democratic officials do enough to staunch the fraud? What more could they have done to cut the fraud off at its knees? And now that ICE is in Minnesota, what more can they do? Are the courts the only recourse, if President Trump does as he has been threatening, and invokes the Insurrection Act?

item.title: President Trumpâ€™s war on birthright citizenship reaches the Supreme Court #shorts
item.author: Vox
item.content:encoded:
After returning to the White House, President Trump signed an executive order stripping birthright citizenship away from the children of undocumented parents and temporary visa holders, which set in motion a series of lawsuits blocking its enforcement. And now, itâ€™s headed to the Supreme Court in a case called Trump v. Barbara.
For well over 100 years, birthright citizenship has been enshrined in the Constitution,with the understanding that anyone born on US soil is granted citizenship.
But in Trump v. Barbara, the administration claims that the law applies to those who are not just born in the United States but also â€œowe allegianceâ€ to it.
The plaintiffs represent a group of people affected by Trumpâ€™s executive order, and their argument is simple: Leave birthright citizenship alone.

item.author: Epic History

Or get a huge $200 off of a Nebula Lifetime plan: https://go.nebula.tv/lifetime?ref=epichistorytv
------------------------------------ In the summer of 1776, the largest expeditionary army in British history arrives off New York to crush the American rebellion once and for all.
Facing the full might of the British Empire, the Continental Army fights desperately to hold New York. But after a series of defeats, General Washington struggles to hold together his forces. Then, in the Revolution's darkest hour, he decides to risk everything to turn back the tide.

item.title: Cities on the ocean - Is our future on water? | DW Documentary
item.author: DW Documentary
item.content:encoded:
Cities, floating on the ocean. It sounds like science fiction, but could soon become reality. Researchers are developing concepts for life on water - on a grand scale. Initial tests are promising. Is success a genuine possibility?
Over half of humanity lives near the coast. But in many places, flooding is a constant threat, forcing entire populations to search for new habitats. Paradoxically, these could be located directly on the water.
Cities, floating on the ocean. It sounds like science fiction, but could soon become reality. International research has long been developing concepts for life on water. Now, new designs â€” from temporary huts to affordable student dormitories to smart high-tech villas â€” seem to hold promise. Could huge numbers of people soon be living in "floating citiesâ€?
This futuristic living concept could have some real perks. Artificial islands can adjust to changing water levels. Modular city â€˜fleetsâ€™ can change location like ships. Flexible floating neighborhoods can expand or move closer together. Efficient water management systems could supply the city with food and energy.
But where floating cities drop anchor, questions arise: What laws do they fall under? What about environmental protection? How do they interact with the ecosystem? And how can they be protected from tsunamis? The search for answers has led to the creation of floating homes in Copenhagen and the Maldives; smart islands in the heart of Seoul; and the world's first underwater greenhouse.
One thing is certain: in the face of climate change, we need to rethink our urbanized way of life. Will we succeed in making "floating citiesâ€ innovative, safe, and sustainable? Could we soon be experiencing a "blue revolutionâ€?

item.title: How an Arctic Resort Builds a Hotel From 30K Tons of Ice and Snow | WSJ
item.author: The Wall Street Journal
item.content:encoded:
Nearly 100 workers race to Jukkasjarvi, Sweden, each November to build the world-renowned Icehotel. They have only weeks to create the entire structure and all the rooms before mid-December, and the materials pose some unique logistical challenges. The hotel includes a main hall, a ceremony hall for weddings and 12 suites custom-made by artists from around the world.
WSJ traveled to Sweden to see the steps and the challenges of how this hotel is made every year from 30,000 tons of ice and snow.

item.title: How Crusader Siege Towers Conquered Jerusalem in 1099 | First Crusade History
item.author: Epic History
item.content:encoded:
In 1099, during the First Crusade, a multinational force of about 12,000 Christian warriorsâ€”led by figures like Godfrey of Bouillon and Raymond of Toulouseâ€”besieged Jerusalem, then controlled by the Fatimid Caliphate. The city's formidable walls, over 50 feet high and defended by 60,000 inhabitants, posed a massive challenge. Starved of resources after a grueling march, the Crusaders turned to innovative siege warfare: massive wooden siege towers.
These wheeled behemoths, up to 60 feet tall, were constructed from scavenged timber, including dismantled ships from Jaffa. Covered in animal hides soaked in vinegar to resist fire arrows and Greek fire, the towers shielded archers and allowed troops to approach the walls undetected. The Crusaders built three: one for Raymond's southern assault and two for Godfrey's northern push.
On July 13-14, after failed initial attacks, the towers rolled forward under cover of night. Godfrey's tower, repositioned stealthily, reached the northwest wall at dawn on July 15. From its top platform, knights like Lethold of Tournai leaped onto the battlements using a drawbridge, overwhelming defenders. This breach allowed Crusaders to pour in, leading to the city's fall after 40 days of siege. The victory resulted in a brutal massacre, claiming up to 70,000 lives, and established the Kingdom of Jerusalem.
Siege towers exemplified medieval engineering, turning a desperate siege into a triumph. They overcame Jerusalem's defenses through mobility, protection, and height, symbolizing the Crusaders' determination and tactical ingenuity in their quest to reclaim the Holy City.
#crusader #siegewarfare #epichistory #epichistorytv

item.title: Red Army vs. Mujahedeen: Soviet-Afghan War Tactics 1980-85 (Documentary)
item.author: Real Time History
item.content:encoded:
Get Nebula with 40% off annual subscription with my link: https://go.nebula.tv/realtimehistory Watch Mad Kings about Kim Il Sung: https://nebula.tv/videos/madkings-kim-il-sung?ref=realtimehistory
The Soviet Invasion of Afghanistan was supposed to be a quick show of force to pacify the country and install a more Moscow-friendly leadership for the Afghan communist regime. But the 40th Army (officially "Limited Contingent of Soviet Troops in Afghanistan") soon found themselves embroiled in a counter insurgency which they weren't prepared for. The tactical successes and increasingly brutal methods against the guerilla mujahedeen tactics didn't win hearts and minds of the Afghan population, however.

Holden Karau - Co-Founder at Fight Health Insurance Julian Wood - Serverless Developer Advocate at AWS

DESCRIPTION Apache Spark contributor Holden Karau discusses the evolution of distributed data processing, the challenges of integrating machine learning with big data tools, and the technical complexities of working with GPUs at scale.
The conversation takes a personal turn as Holden reveals her latest project: an open-source AI tool that helps people appeal health insurance claim denials. Drawing from personal experiences with denied claims, she has built a system that trains on independent medical review data to generate effective appeals, making it freely available at https://fighthealthinsurance.com while grappling with the classic open-source challenge of sustainable funding.

The universe thrums with quantum fields; and the particles of matter and force emerge as vibrational manifestations of the deep symmetries of these fields. The layers and reflections of those symmetries give us the wonderful richness of what we call the standard model of particle physics. Except there seems to be something missing: the sterile neutrino.

item.title: How top songwriters craft the perfect pop song | Think Like A Musician
item.author: TED-Ed
item.content:encoded:
Professional musicians share what makes a great pop song, and how to grow your songwriting skills to make your music stand out.
--
"Think Like A Musician" connects you with working musicians who want to help the music-curious and music-passionate hone and share the gift of music with the world. Part interview, part animated course, our second season "Think Like A Songwriter" features artists sharing their insight on the ins and outs of fine-tuning your songwriting and crafting timeless, memorable music.
Each episode features free supplemental learning materials developed by Education Through Music (https://etmonline.org) â€” a nonprofit with over 30 years of experience developing classroom-adaptable curriculum for music educators.
Directed by Serin Ä°nan, Tolga YÄ±ldÄ±z, Kozmonot Animation Studio.

item.title: Jupiter Made Earth Possible
item.author: Kurzgesagt â€“ In a Nutshell
item.content:encoded:
Jupiter once wandered deep into the inner Solar System. It disrupted rocks, shaped Mars, and helped Earth form. Without it, life on Earth might not even exist. Thanks, big guy.

item.title: How They Prevented The Citicorp Disaster
item.author: Veritasium
item.content:encoded:
The Citicorp centre once had a 67% chance of falling over!
Repairs were beyond necessary but William LeMessurier and his team had to construct supports secretly at night so as not to cause panic.
